title-group.article-title: Applying Ancient Structural Principles To a New Prefabricated Steel System

bio.p: Derry Yu received his PhD from Kyoto University of Japan in 1992. He is a chartered structural engineer and project director with more than 25 years of experience in mixed-use, high-rise projects, in the fields of structural design, research, analysis, value engineering, and overall project management. He is familiar with several structural systems, including reinforced concrete and steel, and has rich experience in seismic analysis and design.

Ivan Kong has been a chartered structural engineer in the United Kingdom since 2009 and a registered professional engineer (structural) in Hong Kong since 2011. Kong has a total of 14 years’ structural design and project management experience on mixed-use, hotel, office, and residential projects, in projects across China, Hong Kong, and the Middle East. He excels at both RC and steel structural design for severe wind and seismic load conditions.

Michael Lu has been a China Class One Registered structural engineer since 2010, a China Registered geotechnical engineer since 2013, and a chartered structural engineer in the United Kingdom since 2015. Lu has nine years of structural design and project management experience. He has solid structural design experience on China’s high-rise and large-scale projects, including office, retail, hotel, and residential buildings, most of which exceed local code limits.

abstract.p: Numerous ancient timber structures located in high seismic zones of China are still standing today, long after experiencing strong earthquakes over hundreds of years. One of the important factors in their longevity is the adoption of the mortise-andtenon joint as the main connection system. The seismic deformation and sliding friction between the tenons and mortises of timber structures can transfer and absorb seismic energy, such that timber structures exhibit excellent seismic performance. Based on the same concept, the authors propose applying a similar joint within a steel frame structure: a new prefabricated steel structure system that adopts connections similar to those of the mortise-and-tenon joints in timber structures.
